title: Severance
descriptions:
Severance (2006) is a darkly comic horror-thriller about a corporate team-building retreat that spirals into a fight for survival. A group of employees from Palisade Defence, a European arms manufacturer, are sent to a remote lodge in the forests of Eastern Europe for a bonding weekend led by their inept manager, Richard. The team includes cynical sales rep Andy, his more principled colleague Maggie, eager-to-please Gordon, jokey Steve, nervous Jill, and a few other office archetypes. Their bus driver refuses to take a dubious mountain road, forcing them to trudge through the woods to a dilapidated chalet that’s clearly not the luxury lodge they were promised.

From the start, the setting feels wrong: locked rooms, sinister war memorabilia, and hints the building was once used as a mental asylum or a military facility. Tensions rise as the team bickers, attempts trust exercises, and tries to make the best of it. Strange incidents escalate—unseen figures stalk the woods, traps are set, and the group discovers files suggesting that Palisade’s products were supplied to brutal regimes and used to arm death squads. The implication is that this very area may have witnessed the aftermath of those deals, with a particularly vicious unit of soldiers rumored to have survived.

As night falls, the team realizes they are being hunted by masked, relentless killers who are disturbingly methodical, as if trained. One by one, the employees are injured or picked off by snares, bear traps, and ambushes. The attacks are laced with dark humor and grisly slapstick—misfired flares, absurd miscommunications, and botched escape plans—yet the violence has a mean edge that keeps the stakes real. Attempts to call for help fail, vehicles are sabotaged, and the surrounding wilderness becomes a maze of lethal obstacles.

Andy and Maggie emerge as the group’s clearest heads, trying to marshal a plan while Richard clings to corporate talking points and denial. The survivors stumble upon more clues tying the killers to Palisade’s past: the company may have covered up a massacre or experimented with drugs to create super-soldiers, leading to a cadre of surviving veterans with a vendetta. Whether the backstory is exactly true matters less than the outcome—the employees are paying for the sins of their employer, the abstract consequences of arms sales made brutally tangible.

The film balances tension with bleak office satire. Team-building exercises invert into survival drills; corporate jargon and risk-management speak become absurd in the face of real danger; and the retreat, designed to smooth over ethical disquiet about selling weapons, becomes a karmic reckoning. Characters who began as clichés gain pathos, while others reveal cowardice or surprising bravery. Richard’s attempts to negotiate, bribe, or explain only expose how detached he is from the human cost of their business.

In a series of chases and set pieces—the group defending the lodge, a desperate run to the road, and a disastrous encounter with an ill-fated jet-setting client—survivors fight back using both improvisation and, ironically, Palisade’s own products. The villains’ identity as hardened ex-soldiers or ex-patients remains somewhat ambiguous, but their skill and discipline underline the theme: weapons and violence don’t vanish after a deal closes; they linger in places and people.

The climax pushes the final survivors into direct confrontation with the killers at an abandoned military compound, where booby traps and industrial hazards level the playing field. Andy and Maggie, bruised and traumatized, manage to outwit their pursuers through a mix of luck, grit, and bitterly comic twists. By the end, the survivors escape, but not without heavy losses and a haunted awareness of what their company’s “success” has wrought.

Severance blends satire and slasher mechanics, using workplace dynamics to puncture corporate hypocrisy while delivering tense, gory set pieces. It suggests that you can’t outsource responsibility: the line from office to battlefield is shorter than it seems, and sometimes the bill for what you sell is paid in your own blood.
